He took part in many solo and group [[Art exhibition|exhibitions]], including the [[Venice Biennale]] in 1976.
==Early life== Kawara was born in Kariya, Japan on December 24, 1932. After graduating from Kariya High School in 1951, Kawara moved to [[Tokyo]]. Kawara went to Mexico in 1959, where his father was the director of an engineering company. He stayed three years, painting, attending art school and exploring the country.<ref name="nytimes.com">[[Roberta Smith]] (July 15, 2014), [https://www.nytimes.com/2014/07/16/arts/design/on-kawara-conceptual-artist-who-found-elegance-in-every-day-dies-at-81.html On Kawara, Artist Who Found Elegance in Every Day, Dies at 81] ''[[New York Times]]''.</ref> From 1962 to 1964 he moved back and forth between New York and Paris.<ref name="February 5, 2015">[[Roberta Smith]] (February 5, 2015), [https://www.nytimes.com/2015/02/06/arts/design/the-guggenheim-shows-first-on-kawara-retrospective.html A Life Captivated by the Wonder of Time: The Guggenheim Shows First On Kawara Retrospective] ''[[New York Times]]''.</ref> He travelled through Europe before settling in 1965 in [[New York City]], where he was an intermittent resident until his death.<ref>[http://www.moma.org/collection/artist.php?artist_id=3030 On Kawara] MoMA Collection. Source: Oxford University Press.</ref>
==Work== Kawara belonged to a broadly international generation of [[Conceptual art]]ists that began to emerge in the mid-1960s, stripping art of personal emotion, reducing it to nearly pure information or idea and greatly playing down the art object. Along with [[Lawrence Weiner]], [[Joseph Kosuth]], [[Hanne Darboven]] and others, Kawara gave special prominence to language.<ref name="nytimes.com"/>
===''Paris-New York Drawings''=== From 1962 to 1964 Kawara made about 200 ''Paris-New York Drawings''. Their motifs include stripes and grids like those of the Minimalist painter [[Agnes Martin]].<ref name="February 5, 2015"/> Other drawings depict installation pieces that fill rooms with networks of string.<ref name="February 5, 2015"/>
===''Today'' series=== [[File:Oct 31, 1973 (Today Series, "Tuesday") On Kawara.JPG|thumb|''Today'' Series date painting at [[Art Institute of Chicago]].]] From January 4, 1966,<ref name="February 5, 2015"/> Kawara made a long series of "[[calendar date|Date]] paintings" (the ''Today'' series), which consist entirely of the date on which the painting was executed in simple white lettering set against a solid background. The date is always documented in the language and grammatical conventions of the country in which the painting is executed (i.e., â26. ÃG. 1995,â from [[Reykjavik]], Iceland, or â13 JUIN 2006,â from [[Monte Carlo]]);<ref>Karen Rosenberg (February 2, 2012), [https://www.nytimes.com/2012/02/03/arts/design/on-kawaras-date-painting-s-at-david-zwirner-gallery.html On Kawaraâs âDate Painting(s)â at David Zwirner Gallery] ''[[New York Times]]''.</ref> Esperanto is used when the first language of a given country does not use the Roman alphabet.<ref name="zwirner">[http://www.davidzwirner.com/exhibitions-2/current-exhibitions/ On Kawara: Date Painting(s) in New York and 136 Other Cities, January 6 â February 11, 2012] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120202122107/http://www.davidzwirner.com/exhibitions-2/current-exhibitions/ |date=February 2, 2012 }} [[David Zwirner Gallery]], New York.</ref>
The paintings, executed in [[Liquitex]] on canvas, conform to one of eight standard sizes, ranging from 8x10 inches to 61x89 inches,<ref name="On Kawara, May 1, 1987 1987">[http://www.christies.com/lotfinder/lot/on-kawara-may-1-1987-4913736-details.aspx?pos=3&intObjectID=4913736&sid=&page=4 On Kawara, ''May 1, 1987'' (1987)] [[Christie's]] Post-War and Contemporary Art Evening Sale, 16 May 2007.</ref> all horizontal in orientation. The exceptions are the three paintings, roughly five by seven feet, executed on July 16, 20 and 21, 1969 â three days when the world was riveted by the [[Apollo 11|moon landing]].<ref name="February 5, 2015"/>
The dates on the paintings, hand-painted with calculated precision,<ref>[[Adrian Searle]] (December 3, 2002), [https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2002/dec/03/art.artsfeatures It's a date!] ''[[The Guardian]]''.</ref> are always centered on the canvas and painted white, whereas the background colors vary; the paintings from the early years tend to have bold colors, and the more recent ones tend to be darker in tone. For example, Kawara briefly used red for several months in 1967 and then returned to darker hues until 1977. Four coats of paint are carefully applied for the ground and each allowed enough time to dry before being rubbed down in preparation for subsequent coats.<ref name="On Kawara, May 1, 1987 1987"/> Eschewing stencils in favor of hand-drawn characters, Kawara skillfully renders the script, initially a [[sans-serif]], elongated version of [[Gill Sans]], later a quintessentially modernist [[Futura (typeface)|Futura]].<ref>[http://www.gms.be/index.php?content=artist_detail&id_artist=30 On Kawara] Galerie Micheline Szwajcer, 1987.</ref> Each work is carefully executed by hand. Some days he made more than one.<ref name="diacenter">[http://www.diacenter.org/exhibitions/artistbio/86 On Kawara - Artist Biography] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110927044942/http://www.diacenter.org/exhibitions/artistbio/86 |date=2011-09-27 }} Dia Art Foundation.</ref> When Kawara was unable to complete the painting on the day it was started he immediately destroyed it.<ref name="nytimes.com"/> When a ''Date Painting'' is not exhibited, it is placed in a cardboard box custom-made for the painting, which is lined with a clipping from a local newspaper from the city in which the artist made the painting; most clippings are from ''[[The New York Times]]''.<ref name="February 5, 2015"/> Although the boxes are part of the work, they are rarely exhibited. Each year between 63 and 241 paintings were made.<ref>[http://www.davidzwirner.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/03/press-release-1999.pdf On Kawara: I Read 1966-1995, March 20 - April 17, 1999] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140301025018/http://www.davidzwirner.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/03/press-release-1999.pdf |date=March 1, 2014 }} [[David Zwirner Gallery]], New York.</ref>
Each ''Date Painting'' is registered in a journal and marked on a ''One Hundred Years Calendar''. When Kawara finished a painting, he applied a swatch of the paint mixture he used to a small rectangle that was then glued onto a chart in the journal. Under each colour is a number showing the painting's sequence in that year and a letter indicating its size.<ref>[http://www.tate.org.uk/liverpool/exhibitions/colourchart/artists/kawara.shtm On Kawara] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110107004315/http://www.tate.org.uk/liverpool/exhibitions/colourchart/artists/kawara.shtm |date=2011-01-07 }} Tate Liverpool, ''Colour Chart: Reinventing Colour, 1950 to Today'', 29 May â 13 September 2009.</ref> The 48 journals<ref name="February 5, 2015"/> therefore record the details of the paintingâs size, color and newspaper headline, while the calendar uses colored dots to indicate the days in which a painting was made, and to record the number of days since the artistâs birth. Kawara created nearly 3,000 date paintings<ref name="wsj.com">Marc Myers (January 30, 2015), [https://www.wsj.com/articles/the-guggenheim-show-silence-spans-on-kawaras-career-1422655735 The Guggenheim Show âSilenceâ Spans Kawaraâs Career] ''[[Wall Street Journal]]''.</ref> in more than 112 cities worldwide in a project that was planned to end only with his death.<ref>[http://www.speronewestwater.com/exhibitions/sculpting-time/installations Sculpting Time] Sperone Westwater, 25 July 2008.</ref>
===''Title'' and postcards=== Much like the ''Today'' series, Kawara uses the number of days followed by the date the work was executed as his life-dates. So the piece entitled ''[https://www.nga.gov/collection/art-object-page.134202.html Title]'' at the [[National Gallery of Art]] has Kawara's life-dates as 26,697 (January 27, 2006) which, when calculated, place Kawara's birthdate at December 24, 1932. Other series of works include the ''I Went and I Met'' series of [[postcard]]s sent to his friends detailing aspects of his life, and a series of telegrams sent to various people bearing the message "I AM STILL ALIVE". Between 1968 and 1979, On Kawara created his information series, ''I Got Up'', in which he sent two picture postcards from his location on that morning. All of the 1,500<ref name="wsj.com"/> cards list the artist's time of getting up, the date, the place of residence and the name and address of the receiver another series of postcards, ''I Got Up At'', rubber-stamped with the time he got up that morning.<ref>[http://www.christies.com/lotfinder/LotDetailsPrintable.aspx?intObjectID=2031746 On Kawara (b. 1932), I Got Up, Sale 8523] Christie's New York, 15 May 2001.</ref> The length of each correspondence ranged from a single card to hundreds sent consecutively over a period of months; the gesture's repetitive nature is counterbalanced by the artist's peripatetic global wanderings and exceedingly irregular hours (in 1973 alone he sent postcards from twenty-eight cities).<ref>[http://www.metmuseum.org/toah/works-of-art/2001.228a-pp ''I GOT UP, 1970'' by On Kawara] [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]], New York.</ref>
===''One Million Years''=== [[File:One million years.jpg|thumb|right|180px|One million years]]''One Million Years'' is one of the artistâs best-known works about the passage and marking of time. It lists each year for the one million-year period leading up to the artwork's conception and the million years that follow it. It is sometimes performed, during which pairs of performers (typically one male and one female for an each segment) read dates from each list in order, simultaneously performing ''One Million Years [Past]'' and ''One Million Years [Future]''.
The artwork was first made in 1969, the year of the Woodstock music festival, major civil protests against the Vietnam War and man's first landing on the moon.<ref>[http://www.southlondongallery.org/page/144/On+Kawara+Reading+One+Million+Years/132 Reading One Million Years, 29 March - 5 April 2004] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714212719/http://www.southlondongallery.org/page/144/On+Kawara+Reading+One+Million+Years/132 |date=14 July 2014 }}</ref> The first audio presentation of the reading of ''One Million Years'' occurred in 1993 during Kawaraâs yearlong solo exhibition âOne Thousand Days One Million Yearsâ at [[Dia Art Foundation|Dia Center for the Arts]] in New York. Visitors could hear ''One Million Years [Future]'' being read, while viewing ''One Million Years [Past]'' and a group of date paintings. The longest public reading from ''One Million Years'' took place at ''[[documenta]]'' 11 in 2002, where male and female participants sat side by side in a glass enclosure taking turns reading dates for the duration of the 100-day exhibition, switching between ''[Past]'' and ''[Future]''. In 2004, the project traveled to [[Trafalgar Square]] in London for a continuous outdoor reading lasting 7 days and 7 nights. Since then, readings and recordings have taken place in cities around the world.
===One-Hundred-Year Calendars=== For his one-hundred-year calendars, Kawara, starting with the date of his birth, systematically marks each day of his life with a yellow dot on the calendars, and registers a completed date painting with a green dot (red dots signify that more than one painting was completed on that given day).<ref name="zwirner"/>
===''Pure Consciousness''=== In ''Pure Consciousness,'' a traveling exhibition initiated in 1998, Kawara lent seven ''Date paintings'' (January 1 to January 7, 1997) to kindergartens and schools in Madagascar, Australia, Bhutan, CÃ´te d'Ivoire, Colombia, Turkey, Japan, Finland, Iceland, Israel, and the United States. At all schools they hang in classrooms, bearing dates that fall within the lifespans of the children.<ref>Adrian Searle (3 December 2002), [https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2002/dec/03/art.artsfeatures It's a date!] ''[[The Guardian]]''.</ref>
==Exhibitions== Kawara's first exhibitions include the first Nippon Exhibition, at the Tokyo Metropolitan Art Museum, in 1953, and at the Takemiya and Hibiya galleries the following year.<ref name="diacenter"/> His work was exhibited at New York's Dwan Gallery in 1967, and his one-person exhibition "One Million Years" was shown in DÃ¼sseldorf, Paris, and Milan in 1971. Kawara's work was included in ''[[documenta]]'' 5 (1972), 7 (1982), and 11 (2002), in Kassel, and in the Tokyo Biennale (1970), the Kyoto Biennale (1976), and the [[Venice Biennale]] (1976).
His work has been included in many conceptual art surveys from the seminal ''Information'' show at the [[Museum of Modern Art]], New York in 1970 to ''Reconsidering the Object of Art: 1965-1975'' at the [[Museum of Contemporary Art, Los Angeles]] in 1995. Solo exhibitions of his work have included the [[Otis Art Institute]], Los Angeles, and the [[Centre Pompidou]], Paris, in 1977; ''Continuity/Discontinuity'' at the [[Moderna Museet]], Stockholm in 1980; [[Museum Boymans-van Beuningen]], Rotterdam in 1991; the Dia Center for the Arts, New York in 1993; and the [[Dallas Museum of Art]].<ref>[https://archive.is/20120802115923/http://www.dm-art.org/PressRoom/Archives/dma_205667 Dallas Museum of Art to Present ''On Kawara: 10 Tableaux and 16,952 Pages'', May 18 - August 24, 2008] Dallas Art Museum.</ref>
Kawara's first comprehensive retrospective, [http://exhibitions.guggenheim.org/onkawara/ âOn KawaraâSilenceâ] at the [[Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum]], was installed in 12 sections according to a plan devised by himself. Two years before his death, the artist offered the exhibitâs curator Jeffrey Weiss a list of oblique titlesâincluding â48 Years,â âSelf-Observationâ and âMonologueââfor each of the sections.<ref>{{cite web|title=On Kawara-Silence|url=http://exhibitions.guggenheim.org/onkawara/|website=guggenheim.org|publisher=Â© 2015 The Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation (SRGF)|accessdate=14 November 2015}}</ref> The exhibition was held February 6 through May 3, 2015 and also featured a live reading of Kawaraâs âOne Million Years.â
==Artist books== Kawara created several [[artist's book]]s: * ''One Million Years'', 1999, Editions Micheline Szwajcer & MichÃ¨le Didier (2 Volumes)<ref name="MoMA_Collection_OnKawara_OneMillionYears">{{cite web |url=http://www.moma.org/collection/browse_results.php?object_id=88213 |title=Collection - One Million Years - On Kawara |publisher=[[Museum of Modern Art]] |accessdate=29 June 2010}}</ref> * ''I MET'', 2004, Editions Micheline Szwajcer & MichÃ¨le Didier (12 Volumes) * ''I WENT'', 2007, mfc-michÃ¨le didier (12 Volumes) * ''I GOT UP'', 2008, mfc-michÃ¨le didier (12 Volumes) * ''Trilogy'', 2008, mfc-michÃ¨le didier (3x12 Volumes) * ''I READ'', 2017, mfc-michÃ¨le didier (6 Volumes)
==Art market== On Kawara is represented by [[David Zwirner Gallery]], New York and [[Yvon Lambert Gallery]], Paris.<ref>[http://www.yvon-lambert.com Yvon Lambert]</ref> In 2007, one of Kawaras "Date Paintings" was sold for $1.8 million at [[Christie's]] New York.<ref name="On Kawara, May 1, 1987 1987"/> Another date painting, ''May 1, 1987'', set an auction record for Kawara when it sold for almost $4.2 million at Christie's New York in 2014.<ref>[http://www.christies.com/lotfinder/paintings/on-kawara-may-1-1987-5792580-details.aspx?from=salesummary&intObjectID=5792580&sid=3a727442-f273-4556-96ce-a711099c12dc On Kawara, ''May 1, 1987'' (1987)] [[Christie's]] New York, 12 May 2014</ref>
==Death== He died in New York<ref name="tagesspiegel.de">http://www.tagesspiegel.de/kultur/on-kawara-gestorben-der-mann-der-die-zeit-zaehlte/10186744.html</ref> on July 10, 2014 at the age of 81.<ref>http://fr.phaidon.com/agenda/art/articles/2014/july/14/on-kawaras-date-paintings-explained/</ref><ref>https://www.nytimes.com/2014/07/16/arts/design/on-kawara-conceptual-artist-who-found-elegance-in-every-day-dies-at-81.html?_r=0/</ref> Kawara's published obituaries state that he was alive for 29,771 days<ref>http://www.art-annual.jp/column-essay/essay/39580/</ref> rather than giving dates of birth and death. Kawara's â³100 Years Calendarâ³ indicates that he was born on December 24, 1932, not on the 2nd of January 1933, as was officially recorded.<ref>On Kawara - Silence, by Jeffrey Weiss and Anne Wheeler, 2015, The Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation, New York</ref> This would make the date of his death, June 27, 2014.
==Influences on contemporary artists== *''onKawaraUpdate (v2)'' (2007) by American art collective [[M.River & T.Whid Art Associates|MTAA]] updates and automates (via software) the process-oriented nature of On Kawara's date paintings.<ref name="update"> M. River & T. Whid, 2007 ''[http://www.mteww.com/update/onkawara/ onKawaraUpdate (v2)]''. </ref> *American artist [[Eric Doeringer]] has recreated a number of On Kawara's projects<ref name="DoeringerKawara">Eric Doeringer, 2005-15 ''[http://ericdoeringer.com/ConArtRec/Kawara/Kawara.html]''. </ref> including making ''Today'' paintings with his own birthday as part of his ''Bootleg'' series.<ref name="BootlegKawara"> Eric Doeringer, 2005 ''[http://www.ericdoeringer.com/bootlegs2/BootPages/btkawara.html]''. </ref> From February 6 - May 3, 2015 (concurrent with the exhibition On Kawara - Silence at the [[Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum]]) Doeringer recreated Kawara's daily ''I Got Up'', ''I Met'', ''I Went'', and ''I Read'' projects and made 30 ''Today'' paintings for his ''Echoes'' project<ref name="DoeringerEchoes"> Eric Doeringer, 2015 ''[http://echoes2015.tumblr.com/]''. </ref> *British artist David Michael Clarke reworked On Kawara's ''Today'' series as ''Today Marriages 1969 - 1999'' (2001).<ref name="mariages"> David Michael Clarke, 2001 ''[http://www.davidmichaelclarke.net/lang=en/text-mulholland.html David Michael Clarke]''. </ref> *In ''Return to Sender'' (2004) British artist Jonathan Monk co-opts On Kawara's ''I Got Up At'' (1968â1979).<ref name="return to sender"> Christy Lange, Tate Etc. issue 4, 2005 ''[http://www.tate.org.uk/tateetc/issue4/boundtofail.htm Bound to Fail] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070914032038/http://www.tate.org.uk/tateetc/issue4/boundtofail.htm |date=2007-09-14 }}''. </ref> *''I am Still Alive'' is an installation piece ''after'' On Kawara by [[Martin John Callanan (artist)]].<ref name="still alive"> Martin John Callanan, 2004 ''[http://greyisgood.eu/stillalive/ I am Still Alive]''. </ref> *''Start it'' is a license to practice On Kawara's individual moments by German artist Stefan Hager.<ref name="start it"> Stefan Hager, November 23, 2004 ''[http://www.transordinator.de/start_it/start.html Start it]''. </ref> *''891'' (2006) by Belgian artist [[Kurt Duyck]] is a Blog Art tribute to On Kawara's ''I Got Up At''.<ref name="iland"> Kurt Duyck, 2006 ''[http://my.opera.com/iland/blog/ 891]''. </ref> *''On Kawara is not Dead'' (2006) by Belgian artist [[Danny Devos]] is a Blog Art tribute to On Kawara's ''I am Still Alive''.<ref name="not dead"> Danny Devos, 2006 ''[http://onkawaraisnotdead.blogspot.com On Kawara is not Dead]''. </ref> *The Japanese artist [[Tatsuo Miyajima]]'s use of numbers is a product of On Kawara's influence on him.<ref name="depth of memory"> Aaron Kerner, 2007 ''[http://www.sfcamerawork.org/journals/journal_src/nahakashi_interview.pdf The Depth of Memory Part 2: An interview with Katsushige Nakahashi] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080227031215/http://www.sfcamerawork.org/journals/journal_src/nahakashi_interview.pdf |date=2008-02-27 }}''. </ref> *In his multipart ''Rwanda Project'', executed between 1994 and 2000 in response to the [[Rwandan genocide]], Chilean artist Alfredo Jaar sent Rwandan tourist postcards to his friends around the world, mailed from neighboring Uganda, bearing the names of people who he'd encountered while travelling in Rwanda, reversing the self-referential content of On Kawara's work 'I am Still Alive'; "Jyamiya Muhawenimawa is still alive!", "Caritas Namazuru is still alive!", "Canisius Nzayisenga is still alive!" etc. *Rakawa.net is a [[micro-blogging]] web-site, which is devoted to honor On Kawara's work and simultaneously offers users to document and to inform about daily accomplishments, based on the question "What have you achieved today?" and optionally illustrated by a picture.<ref name="rakawa.net"> Rakawa team, 2008 ''[http://www.rakawa.net rakawa.net]''. </ref> *''The On Kawara Code'' (2008) by the Canadian artist [[Timothy Comeau]] reproduces Kawara's date paintings and One Million Years books using web-programming.<ref name="incode">T. Comeau, 2008 [http://timothycomeau.com/onkawara/ The On Kawara Code] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080718211744/http://timothycomeau.com/onkawara/ |date=2008-07-18 }}.</ref> *Between 2004 and 2007, [[Candida HÃ¶fer]] realized the project ''On Kawara: Date Paintings'' (2009), which attempts to document Kawaraâs oeuvre at the point where each work is hung in its respective collectorâs home. *Mail artist [[David Horvitz]] has said âI relate to On Kawaraâs work because of its [[existentialism|existential]] and even [[zen]] readings.â<ref>[http://www.westdenhaag.nl/artists/David_Horvitz/1/David_Horvitz_interviewed_by_Jacqueline_Clay_and_Katie_Hood_Morgan_EN/10_09_David_Horvitz-publisher=Gallery Clay, Jacqueline, and Hood Morgan, Katie, âWish you were hereâ Interview with David Horvitz, West Gallery]</ref>

{{Infobox civil conflict | title = People's Uprising Rally, 2013 | partof = | image = [[File:Supporter of Nik Aziz Nik Mat.jpg|300px]] | caption = Supporter of opposition leader [[Nik Aziz Nik Mat]] of [[Pan-Malaysian Islamic Party|PAS]]. | date = 12 January 2013 | place = Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia | coordinates = | causes = | methods = | side1 = Opposition members | side2 = {{flagicon image|Flag of Malaysia.svg}} Government of Malaysia | side3 = | leadfigures1 = | leadfigures2 = | leadfigures3 = | howmany1 = 100,000 to 150,000 people | howmany2 = | howmany3 = | fatalities = | injuries = | casualties_label = | notes = }}
The People's Uprising rally or '''Himpunan Kebangkitan Rakyat''' ([[Malay language|Malay]]) was a rally that was held in [[Kuala Lumpur]], [[Malaysia]] on 12 January 2013. The rally was held by various Malaysian opposition friendly non-governmental organisations and opposition parties in opposition to many of the government policies and decisions that have been claimed by left wing supporters to be unfair and affecting the Malaysian populace. The main venue which the organisers have chosen for the rally is [[Stadium Merdeka]]. The event was also known as the '''KL 112 rally''', where the numbers indicate the date of the event.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2013/1/14/nation/12571834&sec=nation|title=Kudos to cops and KL112 rally|date=14 January 2013|work=The Star (Malaysia)|accessdate=14 January 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130116061009/http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=%2F2013%2F1%2F14%2Fnation%2F12571834&sec=nation|archivedate=16 January 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.malaysiakini.com/news/218831|title=The winners and losers in KL112 - Malaysiakini|date=13 January 2013|work=[[Malaysiakini]]|accessdate=14 January 2013}}</ref>
== Background == According to social activist and icon Hishamuddin Rais, the grievances against the government are many and varied<ref>{{cite web |author=Malaysia |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/litee/malaysia/article/january-rally-to-go-on-even-without-permit-says-activist |title=January rally to go on even without permit, says activist |publisher=The Malaysian Insider |date= |accessdate=17 January 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130216214724/http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/litee/malaysia/article/january-rally-to-go-on-even-without-permit-says-activist |archivedate=16 February 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The following lists of grouses: * The scrapping of the rare-earth refinery run by [[Lynas]] in [[Kuantan]], [[Pahang]]. * To fight against cheating in the general elections by the Malaysian government. * The fair distribution of oil-royalty payments by the Malaysian government to oil producing states. * Free education for all Malaysians.
The election watchdog group [[Bersih]] which organised a number of rallies calling for electoral reform in Malaysia namely the rallies in the Bersih rallies in [[Bersih 2.0 rally|2011]] and [[Bersih 3.0 rally|2012]] has revealed that it is not amongst the organisers of the latest rally but has said that many of members will be attending the rally on their own capacity.
The opposition coalition [[Pakatan Rakyat]] has made a 10-point declaration:<ref>{{cite web|last=To |first=Queville |url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/category/nation/2013/01/12/pakatan-makes-10-point-demand/ |title=Pakatan makes 10-point demand |publisher=Free Malaysia Today |date=12 January 2013 |accessdate=17 January 2014}}</ref><ref>[http://www.thesundaily.my/news/587074 ]{{dead link|date=January 2014}}</ref> * Free and fair elections * Saving Felda * Restoring the rights of Sabah and Sarawak * Increasing the oil royalty to petroleum producing states to 20% * Safeguarding the future of the civil servants * A clean and healthy environment * Strengthening the national language and mother tongues * Freeing of all political detainees * Preserving the Malaysia's national heritage * Better living standards for women
== Lead up to the rally ==
=== Government and police measures === The police have advised the organisers of the rally to hold the rally in [[National Stadium, Bukit Jalil|Bukit Jalil stadium]] instead of having it in Stadium Merdeka.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.malaysiakini.com/news/218623 |title=Malaysiakini |publisher=Malaysiakini |date=10 January 2013 |accessdate=17 January 2014}}</ref>
In anticipation of the protests the government began the closure of Dataran Merdeka to prevent protesters from gathering at that location.<ref>{{cite web|last=To |first=Queville |url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/category/nation/2013/01/11/dataran-closed-ahead-of-rally/ |title=Dataran closed ahead of rally, no FRU deployment |publisher=Free Malaysia Today |date=11 January 2013 |accessdate=17 January 2014}}</ref>
The government has also warned against civil servants from attending the rally.<ref>{{cite web |author=Malaysia |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/civil-servants-advised-against-joining-the-rally-tomorrow/ |title=Civil servants advised against joining the rally tomorrow |publisher=The Malaysian Insider |date= |accessdate=17 January 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141023061410/http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/civil-servants-advised-against-joining-the-rally-tomorrow/ |archivedate=23 October 2014 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
Various public universities in Malaysia echoed the government's warning telling students and teachers not to attend the rally.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.malaysiakini.com/news/218670 |title=Malaysiakini |publisher=Malaysiakini |date=11 January 2013 |accessdate=17 January 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.malaysiakini.com/news/218699 |title=Malaysiakini |publisher=Malaysiakini |date=11 January 2013 |accessdate=17 January 2014}}</ref>
The government-controlled mainstream media gave scant coverage on the rally.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.malaysiakini.com/news/218681 |title=Malaysiakini |publisher=Malaysiakini |date=11 January 2013 |accessdate=17 January 2014}}</ref>
===Chronology=== This is the chronology of the people's uprising rally 2013 or (KL112) that was held in Stadium Merdeka, Kuala Lumpur, Saturday 12 January 2013.<ref>[http://mstar.com.my/berita/cerita.asp?file=/2013/1/12/mstar_berita/20130112091922&sec=mstar_berita MStar Online - Kronologi Himpunan Kebangkitan Rakyat]</ref> ''(Chronology sorted from down to upward)'' * '''4.50 pm:''' The rally was ended with the singing of the National Anthem Negaraku. * '''4.45 pm:''' Recitation of the Muslim prayer by PAS Spiritual Advisor [[Nik Abdul Aziz Nik Mat]] * '''4.40 pm:''' The declaration of the rally by Datuk [[Saifuddin Nasution Ismail]]. * '''4.15 pm:''' The Opposition Leader, Datuk Seri [[Anwar Ibrahim]] gave his speech. Anwar ended his speech, shouting "Merdeka" 7 times in a row. The crowd ensues.<ref>[http://bm.harakahdaily.net/index.php/berita-utama/15900-kejayaan-himpunan-lambang-kebangkitan-rakyat Harakahdaily.net - Kejayaan himpunan lambang kebangkitan rakyat]</ref> * '''3.35 pm:''' DAP Secretary, [[Lim Guan Eng]] gave his speech. * '''3.13 pm:''' National Laureate Datuk [[A. Samad Said]] recite the poem titled 'Di atas Padang Sejarah' or 'On The Field Of History'. * '''3.06 pm:''' [[Blues Gang]] vocalist, Ito sing the anthem of the rally 'Ubah Sekarang'. * '''2.45 pm:''' DAP Chairman, [[Karpal Singh]]; DAP Secretary, [[Lim Guan Eng]] dan DAP Adviser, [[Lim Kit Siang]] arrived at the stadium. * '''2.38 pm:''' Arrival of the Opposition Leader, Datuk Seri Anwar Ibrahim [[Stadium Merdeka]]. * '''2.11 pm:''' PAS President, Datuk Seri Abdul Hadi Awang and PAS Secretary, Datuk Mustafa Ali arrived at Stadium Merdeka. * '''2.07 pm:''' The arrival of Menteri Besar Selangor, Tan Sri Abdul [[Khalid Ibrahim]]. * '''2.03 pm:''' Safwan Anang [[student activist]] giving his speech. He states that all students should use everything in their power to abolish PTPTN loans and University and College Act 1971 be repelled by the government. * '''1.51 pm:''' 40,000 participant entered Stadium merdeka. PAS Vice-President giving his speech. * The event starts with the singing of [[Negaraku]]. * '''1.24 pm:''' Some of the Muslim participant are seen to be doing their [[Zohor]] prayers. The sounds of the [[Vuvuzela]] filled the stadium . * '''1.17 pm:''' Participants from Sultan Road continue their way to the Stadium Merdeka. * '''1.14 pm:''' [[Fuziah Salleh]] gave a speech in front of spectators in the National Basket Ball Stadium. In her speech, she said, the rally was organised to uphold the agenda of the opposition. * '''1.00 pm:''' Participant were ask by the opposition to sit on the road side near the Basket Ball Stadium. * '''12.52 mid day:''' The participant of PUR 2013 moving up to the Stadium Merdeka. * '''12.45 mid day:''' Opposition leaders and non-governmental organisation leaders gave speeches in front of spectators before moving on to the Stadium Merdeka. * '''12.15 mid day:'''Dr. Tan Seng Giaw [[Kepong MP]] arrived at Sultan Road. * '''12.10 mid day:''' [[Unit Amal PAS]] (PAS Security Body) were waiting in Little India, [[Brickfields]] to combine with protesters that came from Amcorp Mall before going to Stadium Merdeka. * '''12.08 mid day:''' The Green Rally President, Wong Tack giving his speech to protesters on Sultan Road. * '''12.02 mid day:''' The protesters in Sultan Road sing together the traditional song "Rasa Sayang" * '''11.14, morning:''' A group of protesters pass by the Maybank Building in [[Bangsar]]. * '''11.25 morning:''' PKR Vice-President, Fuziah Salleh arrived on Sultan Road. * '''10.35 morning:''' Amcorp Mall protesters meet with protesters in [[Universiti Malaya]]. * '''10.20 morning:'''The participant are entering the Federal Highway Kuala Lumpur. * '''10.05 morning:''' PAS Security Wing patrolling Sultan Road. * '''10.05 morning:''' Participant set out to [[Universiti Malaya]] (UM) while holding hands.
=== Non-governmental organisations === The Malaysian human rights watchdog [[Suhakam]] and the Malaysian Bar Council will be monitoring the rally. The Bar Council will be sending in a team of lawyers to anyone who needs legal assistances should they be arrested by the police.<ref>{{cite web|last=To |first=Queville |url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/category/nation/2013/01/11/suhakam-bar-council-to-monitor-rally/ |title=Suhakam, Bar Council to monitor rally |publisher=Free Malaysia Today |date=11 January 2013 |accessdate=17 January 2014}}</ref> Former Bar Council president K Ragunath criticised the Bar Council for showing a tendency to support the opposition.<ref>{{cite web|last=To |first=Queville |url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/category/nation/2012/06/23/%E2%80%98the-bar-council-is-way-above-its-spore-counterpart%E2%80%99/ |title='The Bar Council is way above its S'pore counterpart' |publisher=Free Malaysia Today |date=23 June 2012 |accessdate=17 January 2014}}</ref>
== Protests == There were fears by a Malaysian NGO Solidariti Anak Muda Malaysia (SAMM) that there would be some provocations by the police during the demonstration.<ref>{{cite web|last=To |first=Queville |url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/category/nation/2013/01/12/fear-of-agent-provocateurs/ |title=Fear of agent provocateurs |publisher=Free Malaysia Today |date=12 January 2013 |accessdate=17 January 2014}}</ref> After the rally ended, the [[PDRM]] or the Malaysian Royal Police was praised as they shown tremendous amount of patience and restraint.
[[File:Protesters PUR.jpg|thumb|Participants taking a rest.]]
According to different estimates there were about 100,000 to 150,000 people who attended the rally, which was quite peaceful compared the previous rallies.<ref>{{cite web|last=To |first=Queville |url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/category/nation/2013/01/12/trouble-free-rally-kicks-off/ |title=100,000 rally ends peacefully |publisher=Free Malaysia Today |date=12 January 2013 |accessdate=17 January 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.malaysiakini.com/news/218826 |title=Malaysiakini |publisher=Malaysiakini |date=13 January 2013 |accessdate=17 January 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.malaysia-chronicle.com/index.php?option=com_k2&view=item&id=46455:politweet-says-150k-at-rally-but-assumes-stadium-can-only-house-30k-doesnt-include-all-meeting-points&Itemid=2 |title=Politweet says 150k at rally but assumes Stadium only houses 30k, meeting pts not included |publisher=Malaysia-chronicle.com |date= |accessdate=17 January 2014}}</ref> Many of the rally goers gathered at various points of the city before making their way to Stadium Merdeka where the rally organisers conducted a number of speeches in support of their ideals.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.malaysiakini.com/news/218741 |title=Malaysiakini |publisher=Malaysiakini |date=12 January 2013 |accessdate=17 January 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2013/1/13/nation/12570245&sec=nation |title=Police successfully deploy new management method to maintain order during rally - Nation | The Star Online |publisher=Thestar.com.my |date= |accessdate=17 January 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130115170959/http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=%2F2013%2F1%2F13%2Fnation%2F12570245&sec=nation |archivedate=15 January 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
[[File:Terrorist in the PUR 2013 Rally.jpg|thumb|A rally participant.]]
==Aftermath== The police was commended for the way they handled the rally by both government as well as opposition leaders and from the general public.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/instead-of-brickbats-police-praised-for-restraint-at-rally|title=Instead of brickbats, police praised for restraint at rally|date=13 January 2013|work=The Malaysian Insider|accessdate=14 January 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130116105131/http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/instead-of-brickbats-police-praised-for-restraint-at-rally|archivedate=16 January 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref>

Classical ''Newtonian'' physics has, formally, been replaced by [[quantum mechanics]] on the small scale and [[Theory of relativity|relativity]] on the large scale. Because most humans continue to think in terms of the kind of events we perceive in the human scale of daily life, it became necessary to provide a new '''philosophical interpretation of classical physics'''. Classical mechanics worked extremely well within its domain of observation but made inaccurate predictions at very small scale - atomic scale systems - and when objects moved very fast or were very massive. Viewed through the lens of quantum mechanics or relativity, we can now see that classical physics, imported from the world of our everyday experience, includes notions for which there is no actual evidence. For example, one commonly held idea is that there exists one absolute time shared by all observers. Another is the idea that electrons are discrete entities like miniature planets that circle the nucleus in definite orbits{{ref|Messiah_45_50}}. The [[correspondence principle]] says that classical accounts are approximations to quantum mechanics that are for all practical purposes equivalent to quantum mechanics when dealing with macro-scale events. Various problems occur if classical mechanics is used to describe quantum systems, such as the [[ultraviolet catastrophe]] in [[black body radiation]], the [[Gibbs paradox]], and the lack of a zero point for [[entropy]]. Since classical physics corresponds more closely to ordinary language than modern physics does, this subject is also a part of the philosophical interpretation of [[Philosophy of language|ordinary language]], which has other aspects, as well. == The measurement process == In classical mechanics it is assumed that given properties - speed or mass of a particle; temperature of a gas, etc. - can in principle be measured to any degree of accuracy desired. Study of the problem of [[measurement in quantum mechanics]] has shown that measurement of any object involves interactions between the measuring apparatus and that object that inevitably affect it in some way; at the scale of particles this effect is necessarily large. On the everyday macroscopic scale the effect can be made small. Furthermore, the classical idealization of a property simply being "measured" ignores the fact that measurement of a property - temperature of a gas by thermometer, say - involves a pre-existing account of the behavior of the measuring device. When effort was devoted to working out the [[operational definition]]s involved in precisely determining position and momentum of micro-scale entities, physicists were required perforce to provide such an account for measuring devices to be used at that scale. The key thought experiment in this regard is known as [[Heisenberg's microscope]]. The problem for the individual is how to properly characterize a part of reality of which one has no direct [[empirical evidence|sense experience]]. Our inquiries into the quantum domain find most pertinent whatever it is that happens in between the events by means of which we obtain our only information. Our accounts of the quantum domain are based on interactions of macro domain instruments and sense organs with physical events, and those interactions give us some but not all of the information we seek. We then seek to derive further information from series of those experiments in an indirect way. One interpretation of this conundrum is given by [[Werner Heisenberg]] in his 1958 book, ''Physics and Philosophy,''p. 144f:
We can say that physics is a part of science and as such aims at a description and understanding of nature. Any kind of understanding, scientific or not, depends on our language, on the communication of ideas. Every description of phenomena, of experiments and their results, rests upon language as the only means of communication. The words of this language represent the concepts of daily life, which in the scientific language of physics may be refined to the concepts of classical physics. These concepts are the only tools for an unambiguous communication about events, about the setting up of experiments, and about their results. If therefore the atomic physicist is asked to give a description of what really happens in his experiments, the words "description" and "really" and "happens" can only refer to the concepts of daily life or of classical physics. As soon as the physicist gave up this basis he would lose the means of unambiguous communication and could not continue in his science. Therefore, any statement about what has "actually happened" is a statement in terms of the classical concepts and -- because of thermodynamics and of the uncertainty relations -- by its very nature incomplete with respect to the details of the atomic events involved. The demand to "describe what happens" in the quantum-theoretical process between two successive observations is a contradiction ''in adjecto,'' since the word "describe" refers to the use of the classical concepts, while these concepts cannot be applied in the space between the observations; they can only be applied at the points of observation.
== Primacy of observation in quantum mechanics and special relativity == Both quantum mechanics and special relativity begin their divergence from classical mechanics by insisting on the primacy of observations and a refusal to admit unobservable entities. Thus special relativity rejects the absolute simultaneity assumed by classical mechanics; and quantum mechanics does not permit one to speak of properties of the system (exact position, say) other than those that can be connected to macro scale observations. Position and momentum are not things waiting for us to discover; rather, they are the results that are obtained by performing certain procedures. == Notes == #{{note|Messiah_45_50}}Messiah, Albert, ''Quantum Mechanics'', volume I, pp. 45â50. == See also == * [[Heisenberg's microscope]] * [[Philosophy of physics]] == References == * Albert Messiah, ''Quantum Mechanics'', English translation by G. M. Temmer of ''MÃ©canique Quantique'', 1966, John Wiley and Sons * A lecture to his statistical mechanics class at the University of California at Santa Barbara by Dr. Herbert P. Broida [http://sunsite.berkeley.edu/uchistory/archives_exhibits/in_memoriam/catalog/broida_herbert.html] (1920â1978) * "Physics and the Real World" by George F. R. Ellis, ''Physics Today'', July, 2005 == External links == * [http://www.bohmian-mechanics.net Bohmian Mechanics website] [[Category:Determinism]] [[Category:Experimental physics]] [[Category:Quantum measurement]] [[Category:Randomness]] [[Category:Philosophy of physics]] [[Category:Philosophy of language]] [[Category:Interpretation (philosophy)]]

page.title: Physical theories modified by general relativity

revision.comment: clean up and general fixes, http: --> https:, added [[CAT:O|orphan]] tag, [[WP:AWB/T|typo(s) fixed]]: Therefore â Therefore, using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=March 2016}}
''This article will use the [[Einstein summation convention]].''
The theory of [[general relativity]] required the adaptation of existing theories of physical, electromagnetic, and quantum effects to account for non-Euclidean geometries. These '''physical theories modified by general relativity''' are described below.
==Classical mechanics and special relativity== Classical mechanics and special relativity are lumped together here because special relativity is in many ways intermediate between general relativity and classical mechanics, and shares many attributes with classical mechanics.
In the following discussion, the [[mathematics of general relativity]] is used heavily. Also, under the [[principle of minimal coupling]], the physical equations of special relativity can be turned into their general relativity counterparts by replacing the Minkowski metric (''Î·<sub>ab</sub>'') with the relevant metric of spacetime (''g<sub>ab</sub>'') and by replacing any partial derivatives with covariant derivatives. In the discussions that follow, the change of metrics is implied.
===Inertia=== Inertial motion is motion free of all [[force]]s. In Newtonian mechanics, the force ''F'' acting on a particle with mass ''m'' is given by [[Newton's second law]], <math>F=m \ddot{r}</math>, where the acceleration is given by the second derivative of position ''r'' with respect to time ''t'' . Zero force means that inertial motion is just motion with zero acceleration:
:<math>\frac{\mathrm{d}^2 r}{\mathrm{d}t^2}=0</math>
The idea is the same in special relativity. Using [[Cartesian coordinate system|Cartesian coordinates]], inertial motion is described mathematically as:
:<math>\frac{\mathrm{d}^2 x^a}{\mathrm{d}\tau^2} = 0</math>
where ''x<sup>a</sup>'' is the position coordinate and ''Ï'' is [[proper time]]. (In Newtonian mechanics, ''Ï â¡ t'', the coordinate time).
In both Newtonian mechanics and special relativity, space and then spacetime are assumed to be flat, and we can construct a global Cartesian coordinate system. In general relativity, these restrictions on the shape of spacetime and on the coordinate system to be used are lost. Therefore, a different definition of inertial motion is required. In relativity, inertial motion occurs along timelike or null [[geodesic]]s as parameterized by proper time. This is expressed mathematically by the [[geodesic equation]]: :<math>\frac{\mathrm{d}^2 x^a}{\mathrm{d}\tau^2} + \Gamma^a_{bc} \, \frac{\mathrm{d} x^b}{\mathrm{d}\tau} \,\frac{\mathrm{d} x^c}{\mathrm{d}\tau} = 0</math> where <math>\Gamma^a_{bc}</math> is a [[Christoffel symbol]]. Since general relativity describes four-dimensional spacetime, this represents four equations, with each one describing the second derivative of a coordinate with respect to proper time. In the case of flat space in Cartesian coordinates, we have <math>\Gamma^a_{bc}=0</math>, so this equation reduces to the special relativity form.
===Gravitation=== For gravitation, the relationship between Newton's theory of [[gravity]] and general relativity is governed by the [[correspondence principle]]: General relativity must produce the same results as gravity does for the cases where Newtonian physics has been shown to be accurate.
Around a spherically symmetric object, the Newtonian theory of gravity predicts that objects will be physically accelerated towards the center on the object by the rule
:<math>\mathbf{\ddot r} = GM \mathbf{\hat{r}}/r^2</math>
where ''G'' is Newton's [[Gravitational constant]], ''M'' is the mass of the gravitating object, ''r'' is the distance to the gravitation object, and <math>\mathbf{\hat{r}}</math> is a unit vector identifying the direction to the massive object.
In the [[weak-field approximation]] of general relativity, an identical coordinate acceleration must exist. For the Schwarzschild solution (which is the simplest possible spacetime surrounding a massive object), the same acceleration as that which (in Newtonian physics) is created by gravity is obtained when a constant of integration is set equal to ''2MG/c<sup>2</sup>''). For more information, see [[Deriving the Schwarzschild solution]].
===Transition from Newtonian mechanics to general relativity=== {{main|Newtonian foundation of general relativity}}
Some of the basic concepts of general relativity can be outlined outside the [[Special relativity|relativistic]] domain. In particular, the idea that mass/energy generates [[curvature]] in [[Spacetime|space]] and that curvature affects the motion of masses can be illustrated in a [[Newtonian mechanics|Newtonian]] setting.
General relativity generalizes the [[geodesic equation]] and the [[Einstein field equation|field equation]] to the relativistic realm in which trajectories in space are replaced with [[FermiâWalker transport]] along [[world line]]s in [[spacetime]]. The equations are also generalized to more complicated curvatures.
===Transition from special relativity to general relativity=== {{main|Theoretical motivation for general relativity}}
The basic structure of general relativity, including the [[geodesic equation]] and [[Einstein field equation]], can be obtained from [[special relativity]] by examining the [[kinetics (physics)|kinetics]] and [[dynamics (mechanics)|dynamics]] of a particle in a [[circular orbit]] about the earth. In terms of [[Symmetry in physics|symmetry]], the transition involves replacing [[global Lorentz covariance]] with [[local Lorentz covariance]].
===Conservation of energyâmomentum=== In classical mechanics, conservation laws for energy and momentum are handled separately in the two principles of [[conservation of energy]] and [[Momentum#Conservation|conservation of momentum]]. With the advent of [[special relativity]], these two conservation principles were united through the concept of [[mass-energy equivalence]].
Mathematically, the general relativity statement of energyâmomentum conservation is:
:<math>{T_a}^b{}_{; b} = {T_a}^b{}_{,b} + {\Gamma^b}_{cb} \, {T_a}^c - {\Gamma^c}_{ab} \, {T_c}^b = 0</math>
where <math>{T_a}^b</math> is the [[stressâenergy tensor]], the comma indicates a partial derivative and the semicolon indicates a [[covariant derivative]]. The terms involving the Christoffel symbols are absent in the special relativity statement of energyâmomentum conservation.
Unlike classical mechanics and special relativity, it is not usually possible to unambiguously define the total energy and momentum in general relativity, so the tensorial conservation laws are ''local'' statements only (see [[ADM energy]], though). This often causes confusion in time-dependent spacetimes which apparently do not conserve energy, although the local law is always satisfied. Exact formulation of energyâmomentum conservation on an arbitrary geometry requires use of a non-unique [[stress-energyâmomentum pseudotensor]].
==Electromagnetism== {{main|Maxwell's equations in curved spacetime}}
General relativity modifies the description of [[Electromagnetism|electromagnetic phenomena]] by employing a new version of [[Maxwell's equations]]. These differ from the [[Formulation of Maxwell's equations in special relativity|special relativity form]] in that the Christoffel symbols make their presence in the equations via the covariant derivative.
The source equations of [[Classical electromagnetism|electrodynamics]] in curved spacetime are (in [[cgs units]])
:<math> F^{\,ab}{}_{;b} = {4\pi \over c }\,J^{\,a}</math>
where ''F<sup>ab</sup>'' is the [[electromagnetic field tensor]] representing the electromagnetic field and ''J<sup>a</sup>'' is a [[four-current]] representing the sources of the electromagnetic field.
The source-free equations are the same as their special relativity counterparts.
The effect of an [[electromagnetic field]] on a charged object is then modified to :<math> P^{\, a} {}_{\, ;\tau} = (q/m)\,F^{\,ab}P_b</math>,
where ''q'' is the charge on the object, ''m'' is the rest mass of the object and ''P<sup> a</sup>'' is the [[four-momentum]] of the charged object. Maxwell's equations in flat spacetime are recovered in rectangular coordinates by reverting the covariant derivatives to partial derivatives. For Maxwell's equations in flat spacetime in curvilinear coordinates see [http://www.uic.edu/classes/eecs/eecs520/textbook/node2.html] or [http://scienceworld.wolfram.com/physics/MaxwellEquations.html]
